comments.body: should you add a definition to `lodash.nth` as well?
do not use `?` in callbacks. lodash will always call it with 4 arguments, functions are allowed to ignore arguments.

The first internal call to the customizer doesn't include the 2nd, 3rd, or 4th arguments. Only the recursive calls to `baseClone` seem to include the remaining arguments.

We don't care about this when we're creating the customizers as library users, but shouldn't we take this into account for correctness? Or am I misinterpreting the use of optional parameters? Still a bit new to TypeScript.

I don't have a problem making optional parameters required if there's a good case for it. Just seems like this is the right case to use optional parameters.

Want to get this in so we don't have to keep modifying the library source for TS compilation to succeed.

**TS Coding Standards**
http://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/declaration-files/do-s-and-don-ts.html#optional-parameters-in-callbacks
> This has a very specific meaning: the done callback might be invoked with 1 argument or might be invoked with 2 arguments.

**Lodash API**
https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#cloneWith
https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.4#cloneDeepWith
> The customizer is invoked with up to four arguments; (value [, index|key, object, stack]).

**Lodash Source, as of latest commit**
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/165572022d58d3e39e928b33ff9b9589cc60b67b/dist/lodash.js#L2648 (line 2648)
> result = object ? customizer(value, key, object, stack) : customizer(value);
This is a proper use then. Usually that is mistaken but in this case it is correct.
